chunks.chunk_text: Hello. This is 6 Minute English from BBC Learning English. I'm Rob. And I'm Sam. When we talk about climate change, we usually talk about the effects on the planet or the economic consequences.
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Does climate change make you anxious_.json

chunks.chunk_text: But all the damage being done by climate change is also having an effect on our minds, our mental health.
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Does climate change make you anxious_.json

chunks.chunk_text: But for all of us. In this programme, we'll meet one expert who's investigating the link between climate change and mental health problems and hoping to find some solutions. And as usual, we'll be learning some new vocabulary along the way.
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Does climate change make you anxious_.json

chunks.chunk_text: I think the figure will be high among young people, so I'll say B, 84%. OK, Sam. We'll find out if that's the correct answer later in the programme. The expert I mentioned earlier who's investigating this problem is Dr. Geshe Huberner, Senior Researcher at University
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Does climate change make you anxious_.json

chunks.chunk_text: College London. Here, Dr Huberner explains to BBC World Service programme The Climate Question what she's been finding out.
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Does climate change make you anxious_.json

chunks.chunk_text: Many people who experience a climate change event like flooding suffer from post-traumatic stress disorder, often shortened to PTSD, a serious mental health disorder that can develop after a very bad experience like war or natural disasters like a flood or fire. But according to Dr Huberner, even people without direct experience can suffer anxiety issues
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Does climate change make you anxious_.json

chunks.chunk_text: about what the future holds for our planet. This is known as climate anxiety, sometimes called climate doom, a low level feeling of nervousness or worry about the consequences of climate change. These mental disorders are different in terms of how intense they feel, but Dr Huberner describes them both as adverse, having a harmful or negative effect. In all this doom and gloom, it's easy to forget that many of the things which are good for fighting
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Does climate change make you anxious_.json

chunks.chunk_text: climate change are also good for mental health. Here's Dr Huberner again talking with BBC World Service's The Climate Question, this time focusing on positive things which can be done to help. For example, if we get fossil fuel vehicles off the road, we can improve the air quality and we know that per se can be good for mental health. If we change our road infrastructure to enable more walking and cycling, again we have fewer
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Does climate change make you anxious_.json

chunks.chunk_text: fossil fuel being burned, but also we know that walking and cycling are very good for mental health. If we can change our road layout and create more urban green spaces, we already know that green and blue spaces are good for mental health.
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Does climate change make you anxious_.json

chunks.chunk_text: But also good in itself, per se. Dr Huberner also recommends more urban green spaces, open areas for parks, plants and wildlife, which are built into the design of towns and cities. With creative thinking like this, it may still be possible for today's young people to have a planet worth living for. Speaking of which, Sam, it's time to reveal the answer to my question.
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Does climate change make you anxious_.json

chunks.chunk_text: OK, let's recap the vocabulary we've learned from this programme about climate anxiety â€“ feelings of distress caused by worrying about climate change.
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Does climate change make you anxious_.json

chunks.chunk_text: The Latin phrase per se means in itself and is used when considering the qualities of something on its own,
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Does climate change make you anxious_.json

chunks.chunk_text: in relation to something else. And finally, urban green spaces are areas in towns and cities which are reserved for parks, trees and wildlife. Once again, our six minutes are up. Bye for now! Bye bye!
